options.text: Enheduanna placed Enheduanna at the top of the pantheon as the most powerful deity.

options.label: C
options.text: Enheduanna wrote about the gods and goddesses of the Sumerian pantheon, but did not include Enheduanna.

options.label: D
options.text: Enheduanna's writing was focused on the history of the city of Ur.

multiple-choice.question: What was Enheduanna's legacy, and how did it impact later cultures?

options.label: A
options.text: Her poetry influenced the Hebrew Old Testament, the epics of Homer, and Christian hymns.

options.label: B
options.text: Her writing led to the development of a new form of poetry that was widely adopted throughout the empire.

options.label: C
options.text: Her legacy was forgotten after her death, and her poetry was not studied or performed for centuries.

options.label: D
options.text: Her writing had no impact on later cultures and was only remembered as a minor deity.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Enheduanna's use of the pronoun "I" in her writing, and what did it represent?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the first time an author wrote using the pronoun "I" and explored deep, private emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a new form of poetry that was widely adopted throughout the empire.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a way for Enheduanna to express her own thoughts and feelings without being influenced by others.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a way for Enheduanna to communicate with the gods and goddesses of the Sumerian pantheon.

title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main differences between our conscious experience of the world around us and our conscious experience of being a self?

options.label: A
options.text: Our experience of the world is more visual, while our experience of being a self is more auditory.

options.label: B
options.text: Our experience of the world is more auditory, while our experience of being a self is more visual.

options.label: C
options.text: Our experience of the world comes from the outside in, while our experience of being a self comes from the inside out.

options.label: D
options.text: Our experience of the world is more controlled, while our experience of being a self is more uncontrolled.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the rubber hand illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that our experience of being a self is not unique to our brain.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that our experience of being a self is not affected by our body.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that our brain makes its best guess about what is and what is not part of our body.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that our experience of being a self is not affected by our senses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between perception of the internal state of the body and perception of the world around us?

options.label: A
options.text: Perception of the internal state of the body is more visual, while perception of the world around us is more auditory.

options.label: B
options.text: Perception of the internal state of the body is more controlled, while perception of the world around us is more uncontrolled.

options.label: C
options.text: Perception of the internal state of the body is about control and regulation, while perception of the world around us is about figuring out what's there.

options.label: D
options.text: Perception of the internal state of the body is about figuring out what's there, while perception of the world around us is about control and regulation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main implication of the idea that our experiences of the world and ourselves are kinds of controlled hallucinations?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that we can never be sure of what is real and what is not.

options.label: B
options.text: It means that our experiences are not unique to our brain.

options.label: C
options.text: It means that our experiences are shaped by the biological mechanisms that keep us alive.

options.label: D
options.text: It means that our experiences are not affected by our senses.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main differences between human consciousness and artificial intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Human consciousness is more visual, while artificial intelligence is more auditory.

options.label: B
options.text: Human consciousness is more controlled, while artificial intelligence is more uncontrolled.

options.label: C
options.text: Human consciousness is shaped by biological mechanisms, while artificial intelligence is shaped by software.

options.label: D
options.text: Human consciousness is more unique, while artificial intelligence is more general.

title: How one scientist took on the chemical industry - Mark Lytle

options.label: B
options.text: A letter from a conservationist describing the sudden deaths of songbirds.

options.label: C
options.text: A letter from a writer describing the misuse of DDT on a nearby marsh.

options.label: D
options.text: A government contact from her years working in the United States Bureau of Fisheries.

options.label: A
options.text: "The Silent Ocean"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Balance of Nature"

options.label: C
options.text: "Silent Spring"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Environmental Crisis"

options.label: A
options.text: To kill wildlife indiscriminately.

options.label: B
options.text: To shield crops from insects and protect soldiers from insect-borne diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: To control the threat insects posed to human health.

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the ants in the southern U.S.

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of the overuse of DDT, according to Rachel Carson?

options.label: A
options.text: The evolution of resistant species, which encouraged the development of deadlier chemicals.

options.label: B
options.text: The elimination of pests, with no harm to the environment or humans.

options.label: C
options.text: The accumulation of DDT in the environment, the bodies of insects, and eventually humans.

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in the use of DDT, with no negative consequences.

multiple-choice.question: What was the response to Rachel Carson's book "Silent Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: A call to regulate substances capable of catastrophic harm.

options.label: B
options.text: A dismissal of Carson as a "spinster with no children."

options.label: C
options.text: A rejection of the book's findings and a call to continue using DDT.

options.label: D
options.text: A complete silence from the public and the government.

title: How can we solve the antibiotic resistance crisis? - Gerry Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of antibiotics?

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to combat bacterial resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: By developing new antibiotics that are more effective against resistant bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: By packaging antibiotics with molecules that inhibit resistance.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is one challenge to developing new antibiotics?

options.label: B
options.text: Difficulty in discovering new antibiotics that are effective against resistant bacteria.

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty in developing vaccines for common infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Difficulty in creating new therapeutic techniques like phages and vaccines.
